Title: The です form
Lecon: The “です” form is used for everything and can be translated by “be”. “<#b>X</> is <#g>Y</>” is translated in “<#b>X</>は<#g>Y</>です”. In this situation ‘は’, is called a particle, it’s here to indicate the grammatical structure of the sentence, the ‘は’ is used to identify the topic of a sentence.

Title: The です form
Lecon: In order to use the negative form of “です”, you simply transforme “です” into “ではありません”. ONCE AGAIN ‘は’ is prononce like ‘わ’.
Examples: <#b>Today</> <#r>is not</> <#g>Monday</>  :  <#b>今日</>は<#g>月曜日</><#r>ではありません</>|<#b>I</>’<#r>m not</> <#g>Chloé</> (クロエ)  :  <#b>私</>は<#g>クロエ</><#r>ではありません</>|<#b>I</>’<#r>m not</> <#g>French</> (フランス)  :  <#b>私</>は<#g>フランス人</><#r>ではありません</>

Title: The です form
Lecon: Finally, if you want to ask a question, you just add ‘か’ at the end of your sentence, be it, an affirmative or a negative sentence.

Title: Conjugaison
Lecon: There are two kinds of verbs in Japanese. The first is 五段 "Godan". Godan verbs are the majority of verbs that do not end in "iru" or "eru".
Examples: 行く / い<#r>く</> / ik<#r>u</> / to go|学ぶ / まな<#r>ぶ</> / manab<#r>u</> / to study

Title: Conjugaison
Lecon: The other type is 一段 "Ichidan". If a verb ends with "iru" or "eru", it is most certainly an ichidan.
Examples: 食べる / た<#r>べる</> / tab<#r>eru</> / to eat|見る / <#r>みる</> / m<#r>iru</> / to see

Title: Conjugaison
Lecon: To conjugate a Godan verb in the present and future, you need to change the end of the word. For casual use, use the dictionary form, and “root + <#b>a</> + <#r>ない</>” in negative sentences. In polite form, use the structure “root + <#b>i</> + <#r>ます</>”, or “root + <#b>i</> + <#r>ません</>” for negative sentences.
Examples: Casual - Positive : 行<#r>く</> / Ik<#r>u</>|Casual - Negative : 行<#b>か</><#r>ない</> / Ik<#b>a</><#r>san</>|Polite - Positive : 行<#b>き</><#r>ます</> / Ik<#b>i</><#r>masu</>|Polite - Negative : 行<#b>き</><#r>ません</> / Ik<#b>i</><#r>masen</>

Title: Conjugaison
Lecon: To conjugate an Ichidan verb in the present and future, you need to change the end of the word. For casual use, use the dictionary form, and “verb - ru + <#r>ない</>” in negative sentences. In polite form, use the structure “verb - ru + <#r>ます</>”, or “verb - ru + <#r>ません</>” for negative sentences.
Examples: Casual - Positive : 食べ<#r>る</> / Tabe<#r>ru</>|Casual - Negative : 食べ<#r>ない</> / Tabe<#r>nai</>|Polite - Positive : 食べ<#r>ます</> / Tabe<#r>masu</>|Polite - Negative : 食べ<#r>ません</> / Tabe<#r>masen</>

Title: Conjugaison
Lecon: To conjugate a Godan verb in the past, you need to change the end of the word. For casual use, use “root + <#r>った</>”, and “root + <#b>a</> + <#r>なかった</>” in negative sentences. In polite form, use the structure “root + <#b>i</> + <#r>ました</>”, or “root + <#b>i</> + <#r>ませんでした</>” for negative sentences.
Examples: Casual - Positive : 行<#r>った</> / Ik<#r>tta</>|Casual - Negative : 行<#b>か</><#r>なかった</> / Ik<#b>a</><#r>naitta</>|Polite - Positive : 行<#b>き</><#r>きました</> / Ik<#b>i</><#r>mashita</>|Polite - Negative : 行<#b>き</><#r>ませんでした</> / Ik<#b>i</><#r>masendeshita</>
